+package io.opentelemetry.contrib.jfr;
+
+import io.opentelemetry.trace.SpanContext;
+import jdk.jfr.Category;
+import jdk.jfr.Description;
+import jdk.jfr.Event;
+import jdk.jfr.Label;
+import jdk.jfr.Name;
+
+@Name("io.opentelemetry.context.Scope")
+@Label("Scope")
+@Category("Open Telemetry Tracing")
+@Description(
+    "Open Telemetry trace event corresponding to the span currently "
+        + "in scope/active on this thread.")
+class ScopeEvent extends Event {

replies.bodyText: Haven't done much with the JFR stream, but doubt you will get the actual event class and rather get a generic event type that you can look up name and fields on?
replies.author: sfriberg

timeline.message: Fix CR comments and fix issues after master merge

Rewritten for new context implementation

Signed-off-by: Staffan Friberg <sfriberg@kth.se>

timeline.bodyText:
@jkwatson is this how I should do things to wrap the an existing ContextStorage?
What would be the best way to have this provider detected and enabled as a wrapper when JAR is added on the classpath? Or should it be done through some configuration/code instead?
timeline.author: sfriberg

replies.bodyText: hmm. I don't know if this is right. I don't think you want to return a new storage for each call, but the same storage. Take a look at the GrpcContextStorageProvider and BraveContextStorageProvider for examples. @anuraaga is definitely the expert here, if you have questions after looking at them.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: thanks, will check them. I just quickly looked at the example that was in ContextStorage which was basically done this way
replies.author: sfriberg

timeline.message:
Rewritten for new context implementation

Signed-off-by: Staffan Friberg <sfriberg@kth.se>

timeline.bodyText: Does this class need to be public?
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
yes, since it needs to be possible to register for any user.
ContextStorage.addWrapper(JfrContextStorageWrapper::new);
replies.author: sfriberg

timeline.bodyText: What happens if the event is never committed? Is there a way to detect it in JFR? Then it looks like it could be a nice scope debugging mechanism.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: No way to detect, it basically is just GC:ed never to be seen or heard from again :).
replies.author: sfriberg

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure what this comment is referring to (span processors are always synchronous I guess). Maybe we don't need it? Otherwise if you can clarify what I'm missing would be great :)
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: We have the https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java/tree/master/sdk-extensions/async-processor which could batch things etc. so that the timing for the of JFR event which is handled in the processor would diverge from the timing of the Span itself.
replies.author: sfriberg

replies.bodyText: I see - I forgot about that and think many readers would get more confusion than clarity. If we keep a message, making it more generic might make sense - "JfrSpanProcessor measures the timing of events, so it doesn't make sense to wrap it with any other SpanProcessor which may affect timings. When possible, register it first before any other processors to allow best measurements." Maybe something like that?
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Should we use weak keys for this? It's bad for tracing if a bug means spans are never ended and leaked, but this would cause an actual memory leak I think.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: By the way I've been thinking of shading in https://github.com/raphw/weak-lock-free/blob/master/src/main/java/com/blogspot/mydailyjava/weaklockfree/WeakConcurrentMap.java for our use for a different Context-related use case, if that'll help I can prioritize it :)
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Good catch. By using Guava there should be no need to shade another class
replies.author: sfriberg

timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: nonNull is part of the standard JDK API any reason not to use it?
replies.author: sfriberg

replies.bodyText: Yeah there's a perfectly good literal in Java so we should stick to using it where possible (nonNull was added in 1.8, presumably to aid with streams but I don't consider it idiomatic for normal code).
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Hmm - not really for this PR but this doesn't seem like how shutdown is supposed to work. For example, we would probably stop accepting spans, and wait for spans to end naturally in an exporter when it is shutting down I think. But can't think of any improvement here so just writing for reference.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
Probably would be good to improve the JavaDoc, not sure what 'not yet processed means'.


Processes all span events that have not yet been processed and closes used resources.


Similar for forceFlush


Processes all span events that have not yet been processed.


Sound more like this would be for finished spans rather than span that hasn't been closed yet.
Force flush would commit any ready events, as would shutdown but that would also clear up all resources, which I would take as drop all non-completed spans. Once something is shutdown I wouldn't expect things to continue to flow, unless the CompleteResultCode would wait for all spans, but that would potentially be indefinite.
will remove the event.commit part as that feels wrong here
replies.author: sfriberg

replies.bodyText: Agree we may need to improve docs, or otherwise expectations (maybe spec) for this (again not related to this PR). I would generally call this at the beginning of a graceful shutdown and expect pending requests, and exported spans, to complete before termination. /cc @jkwatson @Oberon00
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: what does "pending requests" mean here? Un-ended spans? Or just spans that were in the process of being sent off to exporters?
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: Does @Label work on methods? Very small nit, but tend to like putting annotations on public API where possible. Alternatively, if we annotate the fields maybe we don't need the getters.
timeline.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Since jupiter, let's remove public from class / methods
timeline.author: anuraaga
